title: Personalized Query Auto-Completion for News Search

author: Lorand Dali, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: I will talk about how to completion for new search and this work was done together with blush and yarn.
I will cover this first introduction, then I'll explain the approach in the query ranking model.
I will describe the data set on which the experiments were done, and I will go through the experiments.
There are three of them.
One is evaluating the ranking of the query suggestion that there is determining which features are most useful in.
Getting a more accurate ranking and finally how many keystrokes you can save the user if you.
Use this query suggestion order.
In the end, conclusions and.

So.
To define the problem, what we are trying to do is.
Suggest to the user some queries when he will start to type the query.
For instance Mo.
Then we try to guess what he meant.
Maybe morning Mother, Monastery, Moon and many others.
So such autocompletion system to be useful it has to accomplish two goals.
One is that.
It has to give accurate suggestion after just a few.
Letters because otherwise the user will spend more time dealing with the system than he would gain.
Also, the the suggestions should be ranked so.
Usually the users focus on the top few suggestions in any ranked list, so the correct query has to be in the first three, let's say.
And Additionally to this we try to make the query autocompletion specific to the user so.
Based on some features which we know about the user, we try to guess which of the queries he meant.
The approach is very simple, so X is prefix of a query which the user has typed until now.
Then we have a set of features about the users.
These are mainly demographic features, but they could be also extracted from the users history, which we don't do in this work.
And from the query we generate candidate of of queries from the prefix.
So in this work this candidate query set is generated very simply is just matching the prefix.
Now what we want to do is to for each query from the candidate queries we try to estimate the probability that this query is the correct one given this features.
And because the data is too sparse to compute this.
Conditional probability.
We split it up and condition on each feature separately so the final score or ranking score of query would be the probability of the query occurring just by itself and.
Multiplied by the the probability of the query occurring given that feature one up to feature.
So just side note here, many of these probabilities could be very small or 0, so we used smoothing technique.
During smoothing technique to to address this.
Yes, it's good.
Is his student during student his last name.
But the method is also good.
So the data set is comes from search logs from new site so.
It's about two weeks of traffic and this mass to 380,000 searches.
250,000 unique users out of which 112 thousand were registered to the site.
For the registered users, we know additional information which they specify when they make their account.
Like age, gender, industry, job and income, and for the unregistered users, we just get the locations from the IP address and we know the time of day when the query was made.
So there are about 80,000 unique queries and they are distributed exponentially.
So there is a few queries which are very frequent, like for instance the weather or crosswords or.
So that important celebrities or politicians would get a lot of queries.
There are very a lot of queries which just appear once or twice.
So in the experiments we split the data chronologically into training set and the test set training set is the first 300,000 searches.
And we evaluate these three things so one is how accurately we can guess what the users actually meant when they start typing the prefix of the query.
That is how often the suggestion makes it into the top three.
Then we try to determine which features are most useful to get higher accuracy here and also how many keys the user has to type less because of this.
So baseline, which we compare to this just ranking the queries by frequency so.
Type the prefix, match all the queries which start with these letters and put the most frequent 1 first.
Here are the results of.

Ranking so.
Here are two different feature sets.
This is for unregistered users where we don't know the demographic information.
This is a registered users now in this column it's written how many letters the user specified.

How often is the 2nd as a third and how often it is one of those three, so.

Both for unregistered and for registered users, it is.

Is higher than by the baseline method.

If it's not in the first 3, then the user types the 2nd letter and we do it again.
If after 4 characters the correct one, we still kind of suggested in the top three, then we assume that our algorithm has failed and we didn't save any keystrokes, so.
Across all queries on average almost 6 case, the user has to type less.
